alert.note: Alert for Middle Rio Grande Valley; North Central Mountains; Northwest Highlands; Northwest Plateau; West Central Highlands (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued May 08 at 9:45PM MDT until May 09 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...LONG DURATION RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FOR THE NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS AS WELL AS THE SANDIA, MANZANO, AND GALLINAS MOUNTAINS THROUGH 9 PM MDT MONDAY DUE TO VERY STRONG WINDS, SEVERAL HOURS OF SINGLE DIGIT HUMIDITY, ABOVE AVERAGE WARMTH AS WELL AS AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE... ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR ALL OTHER AREAS FROM 9 AM TO 9 PM ON MONDAY DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, ABOVE AVERAGE WARMTH AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE... ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FOR THE CENTRAL MOUNTAIN CHAIN EASTWARD INTO THE PLAINS OF NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE... .A dire and critical to extreme fire weather event is underway. This long duration of strong, gusty and potentially damaging winds will continue into Monday along with exceptionally low afternoon humidity and poor overnight humidity recoveries. Above normal temperatures will also persist into the middle of the week along with high Haines indices that will yield very unstable conditions leading to rapid and potentially catastrophic fire spread and growth. While winds are expected to decrease in speed some Monday evening, gusty winds will redevelop over much of the eastern half of New Mexico on Tuesday, leading to another round of critical fire weather conditions. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 9 AM TO 9 PM MDT MONDAY... ...RED FLAG WARNING WILL EXPIRE AT 10 PM MDT THIS EVENING... * AREA AND TIMING...Northwest Plateau, North Central Mountains, Northwest Highlands, Middle Rio Grande Valley, West Central Highlands Monday 9 AM to 9 PM MDT. * 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest winds of 25 to 40 mph with occasional gusts of 50 to near 60 mph. * RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Ranging from 6 to 15 percent each day with long durations of single digit relative humidities as well as poor overnight recoveries for many areas. * IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will spread rapidly and will be very hard to control. Long range spotting and extreme fire behavior will be possible. Outdoor burning should not be done.
info.instruction: Please advise the appropriate officials or fire crews in the field of these extremely dangerous Red Flag Warnings.

area.areaDesc: Middle Rio Grande Valley; North Central Mountains; Northwest Highlands; Northwest Plateau; West Central Highlands
